question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
When $p(x) = Ax^5 + Bx^3 + Cx + 4$ is divided by $x - 3,$ the remainder is 11.  Find the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3.$
inference:
By the Remainder Theorem, $p(3) = 11.$  Hence,
\[243A + 27B + 3C + 4 = 11.\]Then $243A + 27B + 3C = 7.$

Again by the Remainder Theorem, the remainder when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3$ is $p(-3).$  This is equal to
\[-243A - 27B - 3C + 4 = \boxed{-3}.\]Final Answer: $\boxed{-3}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
By the Remainder Theorem, $p(3) = 11,$ so
\[A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 + 4 = 11.\]Then $A \cdot 3^5 + B \cdot 3^3 + C \cdot 3 = 7.$

Again by the Remainder Theorem, when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3,$ the remainder is
\begin{align*}
p(-3) &= A \cdot (-3)^5 + B \cdot (-3)^3 + C \cdot (-3) + 4 \\
&= -A \cdot 3^5 - B \cdot 3^3 - C \cdot 3 + 4 \\
&= -7 + 4 \\
&= \boxed{-3}.
\end{align*}

Again by the Remainder Theorem, when $p(x)$ is divided by $x + 3,$ the remainder is
\begin{align*}
p(-3) &= A \cdot (-3)^5 + B \cdot (-3)^3 + C \cdot (-3) + 4 \\
&= -A \cdot 3^5 - B \cdot 3^3 - C \cdot 3 + 4 \\
&= -7 + 4 \\
&= \boxed{-3}.
\end{align*}
